poem:
**Casting Shadows**

In the northern frost, where ballots shiver,  
a line curls, serpentine, outside Toronto walls.  
Whispers of past echoes—whirlwind, orange, brash—  
haunt the gentle turning of maple leaves with tense breath.  
A record scratched, repeats: early footfalls  
etched like roots in autumn's amber grip,  
holding fast to liberty's fleeting song.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Canada election: polls open as shadow of Trump looms over Liberal-Conservative contest – live updates 2.50pm BST Here are some pictures of voters lining up outside a polling station in Toronto, Ontario this morning as Canada votes in the federal election. 2.32pm BST A record number of people – 7.3 million – have already voted during an early voting period that was held last weekend. That topped the 5.8 million Canadians who voted early at". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
